natural problem: How many sequences of 6 digits $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_6$ can we form, given the condition that no two adjacent $x_i$ have the same parity? Leading zeroes are allowed.  (Parity means 'odd' or 'even'; so, for example, $x_2$ and $x_3$ cannot both be odd or both be even.)
natural solution: Regardless of whether $x_1$ is odd or even, we have 5 choices for $x_2$: if $x_1$ is odd then $x_2$ must be one of the 5 even digits, otherwise if $x_1$ is even then $x_2$ must be one of the 5 odd digits.
Similarly, we then have 5 choices for $x_3$, 5 choices for $x_4$, and so on. Since $x_1$ can be any of the 10 digits, the answer is $10 \times 5^5=\boxed{31,250}.$

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 1 = 5"
and h1 : "f 2 = 10"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 3 \<longrightarrow> f n = 5 * (f (n-1) + f (n-2))"
shows  "f 6 = 31250"

 ### Proof

 Similarly, we then have 5 choices for $x_3$, 5 choices for $x_4$, and so on. Since $x_1$ can be any of the 10 digits, the answer is $10 \times 5^5=\boxed{31,250}.$
 *)

fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 1 = 5"
and h1 : "f 2 = 10"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 3 \<longrightarrow> f n = 5 * (f (n-1) + f (n-2))"
shows  "f 6 = 31250"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

 Similarly, we then have 5 choices for $x_3$, 5 choices for $x_4$, and so on. Since $x_1$ can be any of the 10 digits, the answer is $10 \times 5^5=\boxed{31,250}.$
 *)

fixes x :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length x = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall>i<5. (x ! i mod 2 \<noteq> x ! (i + 1) mod 2)"

theorem

assumes h0 : "num_sequences = (\<Sum>(x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, x6) \<in> {0..9}^6. if (x1 mod 2 \<noteq> x2 mod 2 \<and> x2 mod 2 \<noteq> x3 mod 2 \<and> x3 mod 2 \<noteq> x4 mod 2 \<and> x4 mod 2 \<noteq> x5 mod 2 \<and> x5 mod 2 \<noteq> x6 mod 2) then 1 else 0)"
shows  "num_sequences = 31250"

(* ### Problem

 ### Proof

 Similarly, we then have 5 choices for $x_3$, 5 choices for $x_4$, and so on. Since $x_1$ can be any of the 10 digits, the answer is $10 \times 5^5=\boxed{31,250}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes num_sequences :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_sequences = (\<Sum>(x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, x6) \<in> {0..9}^6. if (x1 mod 2 \<noteq> x2 mod 2 \<and> x2 mod 2 \<noteq> x3 mod 2 \<and> x3 mod 2 \<noteq> x4 mod 2 \<and> x4 mod 2 \<noteq> x5 mod 2 \<and> x5 mod 2 \<noteq> x6 mod 2) then 1 else 0)"
shows  "num_sequences = 31250"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
